trans-unit.source: Create a VM with multiple NICs
trans-unit.target: Create a VM with multiple NICs

trans-unit.source: The multi NIC feature lets you create and manage multiple virtual network interface cards (NICs) on your Azure virtual machines (VMs).
trans-unit.target: The multi NIC feature lets you create and manage multiple virtual network interface cards (NICs) on your Azure virtual machines (VMs).

trans-unit.source: Multi NIC is a requirement for many network virtual appliances, such as application delivery and WAN optimization solutions.
trans-unit.target: Multi NIC is a requirement for many network virtual appliances, such as application delivery and WAN optimization solutions.

trans-unit.source: Multi NIC also provides more network traffic management functionality, including isolation of traffic between a frontend NIC and backend NIC(s), or separation of data plane traffic from management plane traffic.
trans-unit.target: Multi NIC also provides more network traffic management functionality, including isolation of traffic between a frontend NIC and backend NIC(s), or separation of data plane traffic from management plane traffic.

trans-unit.source: Requirements and constraints
trans-unit.target: Requirements and constraints

trans-unit.source: At this time, multi NIC has the following requirements and constraints:
trans-unit.target: At this time, multi NIC has the following requirements and constraints:

trans-unit.source: Multi NIC VMs must be created in Azure virtual networks (VNets).
trans-unit.target: Multi NIC VMs must be created in Azure virtual networks (VNets).

trans-unit.source: Non-VNet VMs are not supported.
trans-unit.target: Non-VNet VMs are not supported.

trans-unit.source: Within a single cloud service, only the following settings are allowed:

trans-unit.source: All VMs in that cloud service must be multi NIC enabled, or
trans-unit.target: All VMs in that cloud service must be multi NIC enabled, or

trans-unit.source: All VMs in that cloud service must each have a single NIC
trans-unit.target: All VMs in that cloud service must each have a single NIC

trans-unit.target: Virtual machines with secondary network interfaces and virtual machines with no secondary network interfaces are not supported in the same deployment, also a virtual machine having no secondary network interfaces cannot be updated to have secondary network interfaces and vice-versa.

trans-unit.source: Internet-facing VIP is only supported on the “default” NIC.
trans-unit.target: Internet-facing VIP is only supported on the “default” NIC.

trans-unit.source: There is only one VIP to the IP of the default NIC.
trans-unit.target: There is only one VIP to the IP of the default NIC.

trans-unit.source: At this time, Instance Level Public IP (LPIP) addresses are not supported for multi NIC VMs.
trans-unit.target: At this time, Instance Level Public IP (LPIP) addresses are not supported for multi NIC VMs.

trans-unit.source: The order of the NICs from inside the VM will be random, and could also change across Azure infrastructure updates.
trans-unit.target: The order of the NICs from inside the VM will be random, and could also change across Azure infrastructure updates.

trans-unit.source: However, the IP addresses, and the corresponding ethernet MAC addresses will remain the same.
trans-unit.target: However, the IP addresses, and the corresponding ethernet MAC addresses will remain the same.

trans-unit.source: For example, assume Eth1 has IP address 10.1.0.100 and MAC address 00-0D-3A-B0-39-0D; after an Azure infrastructure update and reboot, it could be changed to Eth2, but the IP and MAC pairing will remain the same.
trans-unit.target: For example, assume Eth1 has IP address 10.1.0.100 and MAC address 00-0D-3A-B0-39-0D; after an Azure infrastructure update and reboot, it could be changed to Eth2, but the IP and MAC pairing will remain the same.

trans-unit.source: When a restart is customer-initiated, the NIC order will remain the same.
trans-unit.target: When a restart is customer-initiated, the NIC order will remain the same.

trans-unit.source: The address for each NIC on each VM must be located in a subnet, multiple NICs on a single VM can each be assigned addresses that are in the same subnet.
trans-unit.target: The address for each NIC on each VM must be located in a subnet, multiple NICs on a single VM can each be assigned addresses that are in the same subnet.

trans-unit.source: Network Security Groups (NSGs)
trans-unit.target: Network Security Groups (NSGs)

trans-unit.source: Any NIC on a VM may be associated with a Network Security Group (NSG), including any NICs on a VM that has multiple NICs enabled.
trans-unit.target: Any NIC on a VM may be associated with a Network Security Group (NSG), including any NICs on a VM that has multiple NICs enabled.

trans-unit.source: If a NIC is assigned an address within a subnet where the subnet is associated with an NSG, then the rules in the subnet’s NSG also apply to that NIC.
trans-unit.target: If a NIC is assigned an address within a subnet where the subnet is associated with an NSG, then the rules in the subnet’s NSG also apply to that NIC.

trans-unit.source: In addition to associating subnets with NSGs, you can also associate a NIC with an NSG.
trans-unit.target: In addition to associating subnets with NSGs, you can also associate a NIC with an NSG.

trans-unit.source: If a subnet is associated with an NSG, and a NIC within that subnet is individually associated with an NSG, the associated NSG rules are applied in “flow order” according to the direction of the traffic being passed into or out of the NIC:
trans-unit.target: If a subnet is associated with an NSG, and a NIC within that subnet is individually associated with an NSG, the associated NSG rules are applied in “flow order” according to the direction of the traffic being passed into or out of the NIC:

trans-unit.source: *Incoming traffic *whose destination is the NIC in question flows first through the subnet, triggering the subnet’s NSG rules, before passing into the NIC, then triggering the NIC’s NSG rules.
trans-unit.target: *Incoming traffic *whose destination is the NIC in question flows first through the subnet, triggering the subnet’s NSG rules, before passing into the NIC, then triggering the NIC’s NSG rules.

trans-unit.source: Outgoing traffic whose source is the NIC in question flows first out from the NIC, triggering the NIC’s NSG rules, before passing through the subnet, then triggering the subnet’s NSG rules.
trans-unit.target: Outgoing traffic whose source is the NIC in question flows first out from the NIC, triggering the NIC’s NSG rules, before passing through the subnet, then triggering the subnet’s NSG rules.

trans-unit.source: Secondary NIC access to other subnets
trans-unit.target: Secondary NIC access to other subnets

trans-unit.source: The current model in Azure is that, all NICs in a virtual machine are set up with a default gateway.
trans-unit.target: The current model in Azure is that, all NICs in a virtual machine are set up with a default gateway.

trans-unit.source: This allows the NICs to communicate with IP addresses outside their subnet.
trans-unit.target: This allows the NICs to communicate with IP addresses outside their subnet.

trans-unit.source: In Operating systems that use the weak host routing model such as Linux, the internet connectivity will break if the ingress and egress traffic use different NICs.
trans-unit.target: In Operating systems that use the weak host routing model such as Linux, the internet connectivity will break if the ingress and egress traffic use different NICs.

trans-unit.source: In order to fix this, Azure will be rolling out an update in the first weeks of July 2015 to the platform which will remove the default gateway from the secondary NICs.
trans-unit.target: In order to fix this, Azure will be rolling out an update in the first weeks of July 2015 to the platform which will remove the default gateway from the secondary NICs.

trans-unit.source: This will not impact existing virtual machines until they are rebooted.
trans-unit.target: This will not impact existing virtual machines until they are rebooted.

trans-unit.source: After the reboot the new settings will take effect, at which point, the traffic flow on the secondary NICs will be limited to be within the same subnet.
trans-unit.target: After the reboot the new settings will take effect, at which point, the traffic flow on the secondary NICs will be limited to be within the same subnet.

trans-unit.source: If the users want to enable secondary NICs to talk outside its own subnet, they will have to add an entry in the routing table to configure the gateway as described below.
trans-unit.target: If the users want to enable secondary NICs to talk outside its own subnet, they will have to add an entry in the routing table to configure the gateway as described below.

trans-unit.source: Configure Linux VMs
trans-unit.target: Configure Linux VMs

trans-unit.source: For Linux VMs, since the default behavior uses weak host routing, we recommend that the secondary NICs are restricted to traffic flows only within the same subnet.
trans-unit.target: For Linux VMs, since the default behavior uses weak host routing, we recommend that the secondary NICs are restricted to traffic flows only within the same subnet.

trans-unit.source: However if certain scenarios demand connectivity outside the subnet, users should enable policy based routing to ensure that the ingress and egress traffic uses the same NIC.
trans-unit.target: However if certain scenarios demand connectivity outside the subnet, users should enable policy based routing to ensure that the ingress and egress traffic uses the same NIC.
